content.text: Once upon a time, in a lush green forest by the banks of a wide, sparkling river, there lived a clever little monkey named Muthu.
Muthu was small but quick-witted, with golden-brown fur that shimmered in the sunlight and a long, curly tail that swung playfully as he leaped from branch to branch.
He loved to eat the sweetest, ripest mangoes that grew high up in the trees, and he spent his days swinging through the forest, laughing and chattering with his friends.
One sunny morning, as Muthu was enjoying a particularly juicy mango, he heard a loud *SPLASH!* from the river below.
Curious, he peered down and saw a large crocodile named Kali basking on a rock.
Kali had rough, scaly skin, sharp teeth, and a long, powerful tail.
He was known throughout the forest for being sly and cunning, but Muthu wasn’t afraid—he was too clever to be tricked by a crocodile!
Kali looked up and saw Muthu munching on his mango. His mouth watered.
"Oh, what a delicious-looking mango!" he thought.
"But even more delicious would be that plump little monkey!" So, he called out in his smoothest voice, "Good morning, dear monkey!
What a fine day it is!"  Muthu, perched safely on his branch, replied, "Good morning, Mr. Crocodile!
Yes, it is a lovely day indeed."  Kali smiled, showing his sharp teeth.
"I couldn’t help but notice how sweet your mango looks.
Would you be so kind as to share some with me?
I’ve been so hungry, and the fish in the river just don’t satisfy me like a ripe mango would."  Muthu thought for a moment.
He didn’t trust Kali, but he also didn’t want to be rude. "Of course!" he said.
"But the best mangoes grow on the other side of the river.
If you swim me across, I’ll pick the sweetest one for you!"  Kali’s eyes gleamed.
"What a wonderful idea!" he said. "Climb onto my back, and I’ll take you there at once."  Muthu hesitated.
He knew crocodiles were dangerous, but he also knew he had to be smarter than Kali.
So, he hopped onto Kali’s back, holding tightly to his scaly neck.
As they glided into the river, Kali began to swim slowly, savoring the moment.
Then, just as they reached the middle of the river, he turned his head and grinned.
"You know, little monkey," he said, "my mother has been very ill.
The only thing that can cure her is the heart of a monkey.
And since you’re already here…"  Muthu’s heart pounded, but he didn’t panic.
He thought quickly and then let out a sad sigh.
"Oh, dear Kali," he said, "why didn’t you tell me sooner? I would have brought my heart with me!
But I left it back in my tree. It’s hanging on a branch, safe and sound.
If you take me back, I’ll fetch it for you right away!"  Kali frowned.
"You left your heart in the tree? That’s ridiculous! No one does that!"  Muthu shook his head.
"Oh, but we monkeys do! We always leave our hearts in the trees when we go for a swim.
It’s much safer that way. Didn’t you know?"  Kali scratched his head with a claw.
He wasn’t sure if Muthu was telling the truth, but he didn’t want to risk losing his prize.
"Very well," he grumbled. "I’ll take you back.
But don’t try to trick me!"  As soon as they reached the riverbank, Muthu leaped off Kali’s back and scrambled up the nearest tree.
He swung from branch to branch until he was high above the crocodile. "You foolish crocodile!" he laughed.
"Did you really think I would carry my heart with me? Hearts stay inside us, where they belong!
Now, go back to your river and leave me in peace!"  Kali snarled in frustration.
He had been outsmarted by a little monkey!
With a flick of his tail, he disappeared beneath the water, vowing never to be tricked again.
From that day on, Muthu was even more careful when he ventured near the river.
He knew that not all creatures could be trusted, but he also knew that with cleverness and quick thinking, he could always outsmart them.
And so, he lived happily in his forest, swinging from tree to tree, eating the sweetest mangoes, and sharing his adventures with his friends.
And as for Kali? Well, he learned his lesson too.
He never tried to trick a monkey again—and he stuck to eating fish for the rest of his days.
The end.
